mn5:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
mn5:1.3: There Venerable Sāriputta addressed the bhikkhus:
mn5:2.1: “Friends, these four people are found in the world.
mn5:2.3: One person with a blemish doesn’t understand as it is: ‘There is a blemish in me.’
mn5:2.4: But another person with a blemish does understand as it is: ‘There is a blemish in me.’
mn5:2.5: One person without a blemish doesn’t understand as it is: ‘There is no blemish in me.’
mn5:2.6: But another person without a blemish does understand as it is: ‘There is no blemish in me.’
mn5:2.7: In this case, of the two persons with a blemish, the one who doesn’t understand is said to be worse,
mn5:2.8: while the one who does understand is better.
mn5:2.9: And of the two persons without a blemish, the one who doesn’t understand is said to be worse,
mn5:2.10: while the one who does understand is better.”
mn5:3.1: When he said this, Venerable Mahāmoggallāna said to him:
mn5:3.2: “What is the cause, Friend Sāriputta, what is the reason why, of the two persons with a blemish, one is said to be worse and one better?
mn5:3.3: And what is the cause, what is the reason why, of the two persons without a blemish, one is said to be worse and one better?”
mn5:4.1: “Friend, take the case of the person who has a blemish and does not understand it. You can expect that they won’t generate desire, strive, or make an effort to give up that blemish.
mn5:4.2: And they will die with passion, aversion, and muddledness, blemished, with a defiled mind.
mn5:4.3: Suppose a bronze dish was brought from a shop or smithy covered with dirt or stains.
mn5:4.4: And the owners neither used it or had it cleaned, but kept it in a dirty place.
mn5:4.5: Over time, wouldn’t that bronze dish get even dirtier and more stained?”
mn5:4.7: “In the same way, take the case of the person who has a blemish and does not understand it. You can expect that …
mn5:4.8: they will die with a defiled mind.
mn5:5.1: Take the case of the person who has a blemish and does understand it. You can expect that they will generate desire, strive, and make an effort to give up that blemish.
mn5:5.2: And they will die without passion, aversion, and muddledness, unblemished, with an undefiled mind.
mn5:5.3: Suppose a bronze dish was brought from a shop or smithy covered with dirt or stains.
mn5:5.4: But the owners used it and had it cleaned, and didn’t keep it in a dirty place.
mn5:5.5: Over time, wouldn’t that bronze dish get cleaner and brighter?”
mn5:5.7: “In the same way, take the case of the person who has a blemish and does understand it. You can expect that …
mn5:5.8: they will die with an undefiled mind.
mn5:6.1: Take the case of the person who doesn’t have a blemish but does not understand it. You can expect that they will apply their mind to the significance of beauty, and because of that, passion will infect their mind.
mn5:6.2: And they will die with passion, aversion, and muddledness, blemished, with a defiled mind.
mn5:6.3: Suppose a bronze dish was brought from a shop or smithy clean and bright.
mn5:6.4: And the owners neither used it or had it cleaned, but kept it in a dirty place.
mn5:6.5: Over time, wouldn’t that bronze dish get dirtier and more stained?”
mn5:6.7: “In the same way, take the case of the person who has no blemish and does not understand it. You can expect that …
mn5:6.8: they will die with a defiled mind.
mn5:7.1: Take the case of the person who doesn’t have a blemish and does understand it. You can expect that they won’t apply their mind to the significance of beauty, and because of that, passion won’t infect their mind.
mn5:7.2: And they will die without passion, aversion, and muddledness, unblemished, with an undefiled mind.
mn5:7.3: Suppose a bronze dish was brought from a shop or smithy clean and bright.
mn5:7.4: And the owners used it and had it cleaned, and didn’t keep it in a dirty place.
mn5:7.5: Over time, wouldn’t that bronze dish get cleaner and brighter?”
mn5:7.7: “In the same way, take the case of the person who doesn’t have a blemish and does understand it. You can expect that …
mn5:7.8: they will die with an undefiled mind.
mn5:8.1: This is the cause, this is the reason why, of the two persons with a blemish, one is said to be worse and one better.
mn5:8.2: And this is the cause, this is the reason why, of the two persons without a blemish, one is said to be worse and one better.”
mn5:9.2: But what is ‘blemish’ a term for?”
mn5:9.3: “Friend, ‘blemish’ is a term for the spheres of harmful, unfavorable wishes.
mn5:10.1: It’s possible that some bhikkhu might wish:
mn5:10.2: ‘If I commit an offense, I hope the bhikkhus don’t find out!’
mn5:10.3: But it’s possible that the bhikkhus do find out that that bhikkhu
mn5:10.5: Thinking, ‘The bhikkhus have found out about my offense,’
mn5:10.7: And that anger and that bitterness
mn5:11.1: It’s possible that some bhikkhu might wish:
mn5:11.2: ‘If I commit an offense, I hope the bhikkhus accuse me in private, not in the middle of the Saṅgha.’
mn5:11.3: But it’s possible that the bhikkhus do accuse that bhikkhu in the middle of the Saṅgha …
mn5:12.1: It’s possible that some bhikkhu might wish:
mn5:12.2: ‘If I commit an offense, I hope I’m accused by an equal, not by someone who is not an equal.’
mn5:12.3: But it’s possible that someone who is not an equal accuses that bhikkhu …
mn5:13.1: It’s possible that some bhikkhu might wish:
mn5:13.2: ‘Oh, I hope the Teacher will teach the bhikkhus by repeatedly questioning me alone, not some other bhikkhu.’
mn5:13.3: But it’s possible that the Teacher will teach the bhikkhus by repeatedly questioning some other bhikkhu …
mn5:14.1: It’s possible that some bhikkhu might wish:
mn5:14.2: ‘Oh, I hope the bhikkhus will enter the village for the meal putting me at the very front, not some other bhikkhu.’
mn5:14.3: But it’s possible that the bhikkhus will enter the village for the meal putting some other bhikkhu at the very front …
mn5:15.1: It’s possible that some bhikkhu might wish:
mn5:15.2: ‘Oh, I hope that I alone get the best seat, the best drink, and the best almsfood in the refectory, not some other bhikkhu.’
mn5:15.3: But it’s possible that some other bhikkhu gets the best seat, the best drink, and the best almsfood in the refectory …
mn5:16.1: It’s possible that some bhikkhu might wish:
mn5:16.2: ‘I hope that I alone give the appreciation after the meal in the refectory, not some other bhikkhu.’
mn5:16.3: But it’s possible that some other bhikkhu gives the appreciation after the meal in the refectory …
mn5:17.1: It’s possible that some bhikkhu might wish:
mn5:17.2: ‘Oh, I hope that I might teach the Dhamma to the bhikkhus, nuns, laymen, and laywomen in the monastery, not some other bhikkhu.’
mn5:18-20.5: But it’s possible that some other bhikkhu teaches the Dhamma …
mn5:21.1: It’s possible that some bhikkhu might wish:
mn5:21.2: ‘Oh, I hope that the bhikkhus, nuns, laymen, and laywomen will honor, respect, revere, and venerate me alone, not some other bhikkhu.’
mn5:22-24.5: But it’s possible that some other bhikkhu is honored, respected, revered, and venerated …
mn5:25.1: It’s possible that some bhikkhu might wish:
mn5:25.2: ‘I hope I get the nicest robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick, not some other bhikkhu.’
mn5:25.3: But it’s possible that some other bhikkhu gets the nicest robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick …
mn5:26-27.6: Thinking, ‘Some other bhikkhu has got the nicest robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick’,
mn5:26-27.8: And that anger and that bitterness
mn5:28.1: ‘Blemish’ is a term for these spheres of harmful, unfavorable wishes.
mn5:29.1: Suppose these spheres of harmful, unfavorable wishes are seen and heard to be not given up by a bhikkhu. Even though he lives in the wilderness, in remote lodgings, eats only almsfood, wanders indiscriminately for almsfood, wears rag robes, and wears shabby robes, his fellow renunciates don’t honor, respect, revere, and venerate him.
mn5:29.3: It’s because these spheres of harmful, unfavorable wishes are seen and heard to be not given up by that venerable.
mn5:29.4: Suppose a bronze dish was brought from a shop or smithy clean and bright.
mn5:29.5: Then the owners were to prepare it with the carcass of a snake, a dog, or a human, cover it with a bronze lid, and parade it through the market-place.
mn5:29.6: When people saw it they’d say:
mn5:29.7: ‘My good man, what is it that you’re carrying like a precious treasure?’
mn5:29.8: So they’d open up the lid for people to look inside.
mn5:29.9: But as soon as they saw it they were filled with loathing, revulsion, and disgust.
mn5:29.10: Not even those who were hungry wanted to eat it, let alone those who had eaten.
mn5:29.11: In the same way, when these spheres of harmful, unfavorable wishes are seen and heard to be not given up by a bhikkhu … his fellow renunciates don’t honor, respect, revere, and venerate him.
mn5:29.13: It’s because these spheres of harmful, unfavorable wishes are seen and heard to be not given up by that venerable.
mn5:30.1: Suppose these spheres of harmful, unfavorable wishes are seen and heard to be given up by a bhikkhu. Even though he lives within a village, accepts invitations to a meal, and wears robes offered by householders, his fellow renunciates honor, respect, revere, and venerate him.
mn5:30.3: It’s because these spheres of harmful, unfavorable wishes are seen and heard to be given up by that venerable.
mn5:30.4: Suppose a bronze dish was brought from a shop or smithy clean and bright.
mn5:30.5: Then the owners were to prepare it with boiled fine rice with the dark grains picked out and served with many soups and sauces, cover it with a bronze lid, and parade it through the market-place.
mn5:30.6: When people saw it they’d say:
mn5:30.7: ‘My good man, what is it that you’re carrying like a precious treasure?’
mn5:30.8: So they’d open up the lid for people to look inside.
mn5:30.9: And as soon as they saw it they were filled with liking, attraction, and relish.
mn5:30.10: Even those who had eaten wanted to eat it, let alone those who were hungry.
mn5:30.11: In the same way, when these spheres of harmful, unfavorable wishes are seen and heard to be given up by a bhikkhu … his fellow renunciates honor, respect, revere, and venerate him.
mn5:30.13: It’s because these spheres of harmful, unfavorable wishes are seen and heard to be given up by that venerable.”
mn5:31.1: When he said this, Venerable Mahāmoggallāna said to him,
mn5:31.2: “Friend Sāriputta, a simile springs to mind.”
mn5:31.3: “Then speak as you feel inspired,” said Venerable Sāriputta.
mn5:31.4: “Friend, at one time I was staying right here in Rājagaha, the Mountainfold.
mn5:31.5: Then I robed up in the morning and, taking my bowl and robe, entered Rājagaha for alms.
mn5:31.6: Now at that time Samīti of the wainwrights was planing the rim of a chariot wheel.
mn5:31.7: The Ājīvaka ascetic Paṇḍuputta, who was formerly of the wainwrights, was standing by,
mn5:31.8: and this thought came to his mind:
mn5:31.9: ‘Oh, I hope Samīti the wainwright planes out the crooks, bends, and flaws in this rim. Then the rim will be rid of crooks, bends, and flaws, pure and established in the pith.’
mn5:31.10: And Samīti planed out the flaws in the rim just as Paṇḍuputta thought.
mn5:31.12: ‘He planes like he knows my heart with his heart!’
mn5:32.1: In the same way, there are those faithless people who went forth from the lay life to homelessness not out of faith but to earn a livelihood. They’re devious, deceitful, and sneaky. They’re restless, insolent, fickle, scurrilous, and loose-tongued. They do not guard their sense doors or eat in moderation, and they are not dedicated to wakefulness. They don’t care about the ascetic life, and don’t keenly respect the training. They’re indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion, lazy, and lacking effort. They’re forgetful, lacking comprehension and composure, with straying minds, witless and foolish. Venerable Sāriputta planes their faults with this exposition of the Dhamma as if he knows my heart with his heart!
mn5:32.2: But there are those gentlemen who went forth from the lay life to homelessness out of faith. They’re not devious, deceitful, and sneaky. They’re not restless, insolent, fickle, scurrilous, and loose-tongued. They guard their sense doors and eat in moderation, and they are dedicated to wakefulness. They care about the ascetic life, and keenly respect the training. They’re not indulgent or slack, nor are they leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion. They’re effortful and determined. Their recollection is established, and they are comprehending and composed, with unified minds; possessing understanding, not foolish. Hearing this exposition of the Dhamma from Venerable Sāriputta, they drink it up and devour it, as it were. And in speech and thought they say:
mn5:32.3: ‘It’s good, sirs, that he draws his fellow renunciates away from the unfavorable and establishes them in the favorable.’
mn5:33.1: Suppose there was a woman or man who was young, youthful, and fond of adornments, and had bathed their head. Presented with a garland of lotuses, jasmine, or liana flowers, they would take them in both hands and place them on the crown of the head.
mn5:33.2: In the same way, those gentlemen who went forth from the lay life to homelessness out of faith … say:
mn5:33.3: ‘It’s good, sirs, that he draws his fellow renunciates away from the unfavorable and establishes them in the favorable.’”
mn5:33.4: And so these two spiritual giants appreciated each other’s fine words.
